visibility_factors: fog/mist lingering late morning through afternoon

alert_summary.description: River rises/possible ice jams; not a direct road-snow/ice headline. Expires Thu 2/19 1:30 PM.

meteorology.overall_conditions_summary: For Rockford, MI on Thu 2/19/2026 the dominant school-impact weather is freezing fog around the morning bus window, not snow. Temps fall to around 30–31°F from ~5–9 AM with light winds; wind chills bottom out near ~24°F (NOT a cold-closure situation). With no snow expected and only light drizzle late evening, the main risk is slick spots/black ice from freezing fog deposition on untreated bridges/side roads plus reduced visibility. In a Michigan district with normal winter operations, this setup strongly favors SCHOOL OPEN, with a small chance of a 1–2 hour delay if freezing fog becomes dense and widespread right at 6–8 AM.

similar_weather_patterns.pattern_description: Late-winter warm-advection/"thaw" day: temps hovering near/just below freezing pre-dawn with saturated low levels (fog/freezing fog), then rising above freezing into the upper 30s/low 40s. Little/no snow, light liquid precip.

Freeze–thaw with dense fog at bus time after a mild/rainy prior day (wet roads + rapid cooling to ~30–31°F), creating patchy black ice on untreated rural/bridge surfaces despite minimal measured precip.

Hydrologic-thaw setup (rain + melting + very high humidity) where the *main* operational issue is localized flooding/ponding and reduced visibility, not plowable snow. Closures tend to be rare and localized (more often delays).

seasonal_context.typical_conditions_for_date: For Rockford (Kent County) in mid-to-late February, it’s normally peak winter readiness: crews are staffed, salt/plow routes are well-practiced, and the community is highly adapted. A day with highs near 41°F and no snowfall is not a classic Michigan snow-day profile; it’s more of a thaw/transition day where the risk shifts to *ice* and *visibility* around sunrise.
unusual_factors: Freezing fog explicitly forecast from ~5 AM through ~9 AM (and temps ~30–31°F at 6–8 AM): this is a genuine ‘ice-risk’ signal even with near-zero QPF overnight.
Very high humidity (upper 90s) and fog much of the day: reduced visibility can be a bus-safety issue, especially on rural roads.

Antecedent conditions matter: you have a warm/rainy pattern on Wed 2026-02-18 (substantial rain shown in the dataset) followed by a drop to near/below freezing overnight—classic setup for patchy refreeze on bridges/overpasses and untreated backroads.
NWS Hydrologic Outlook in effect through Thu early afternoon: not a school-closure driver by itself, but it flags ongoing melt/rises and the ‘messy shoulder-season’ nature of this event.

local_microclimates: Low-lying areas along the Rogue River corridor and other sheltered valleys can hold colder air longer at dawn, increasing freezing-fog/black-ice odds while nearby main roads improve faster.
Bridges/overpasses on M-44/US-131 connectors and elevated rural spans tend to freeze first during refreeze nights.
Rural fringe routes north/east of Rockford (open fields) often have more localized slick spots than the urban core where traffic and treatment are better.
infrastructure_considerations: West Michigan districts (including Rockford area) generally handle light snow/rain easily; closures usually require significant snow, widespread glaze ice, or blizzard-level impacts.
This forecast has *no accumulating snow* and light precip—so the decision will hinge on whether freezing fog produces a thin glaze/black ice during the 6:30–7:30 AM bus window.
If road commissions pre-treat Wednesday evening, the closure probability drops sharply; if temps fall faster than expected and treatment is washed off/ineffective, risk rises.
location_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Small elevation differences (a few hundred feet) still matter on marginal temp mornings: higher, more exposed areas may dry out and improve earlier with wind; low spots stay icy/foggy longer.

history.confidence_assessment: Overall **medium-high confidence** that a full snow day is unlikely because there is **0" snow**, modest wind, and temps rise above freezing after mid-morning. However, the **freezing fog from ~5–9 AM with temps ~30–31°F** is the one credible Michigan-style closure trigger (usually more often a **delay** than a closure). A reasonable Rockford-area closure probability for Thu 2026-02-19 is **~10–20% for a full closure**, with a higher **~25–40% chance of a 1–2 hour delay** if freezing fog produces widespread slick spots at bus time.

safety_recommendations: Treat this as an ICE/visibility morning, not a snow morning: freezing fog is flagged 5–9 AM with temps ~30–31°F, which can glaze bridges, overpasses, and shaded rural pavement even if roads looked merely wet late Wednesday.

Coordinate with road commission/MDOT for early-morning salt runs on known slick spots (bridges on US-131/M-44 corridors, ramps, and north-facing curves) and ensure bus drivers are warned about “looks wet = is ice” conditions.

Run a very early route-check (or driver spot reports) on the district’s rural/low-traffic roads and hillier segments; those are the most likely to stay slick until temps rise above freezing mid-morning.
Expect reduced visibility: fog/freezing fog around sunrise can reduce sight distance at student crossings and bus stops; consider holding buses a few minutes if dense fog is observed locally.
Increase loading-zone traction plans: salt/sand bus loops, parent drop-off, and sidewalks before 6:30 AM—these areas ice up first from refreeze and foot traffic compaction.
Message families to allow extra stopping distance and to use extreme caution near intersections/crosswalks in fog; emphasize lights, slower speeds, and avoiding sudden braking.
If freezing fog is dense at 6–8 AM (visibility suddenly drops), a DELAY is more operationally justified than a full closure in Michigan given low precip and warming trend.

local_news.summary: A system impacting Michigan Feb 17–18 brings mixed precip; primary icing risk (up to ~0.20") is forecast mainly north of U.S. 10 and east of US-131 (e.g., Clare/Osceola). Article does not specifically flag Kent County/Rockford for significant snow/ice during this window, but notes additional precipitation possible Friday.

local_news.summary: Recent weather-related multi-vehicle crash on NB US-131 near Burton with additional freeway accidents reported the same night—useful context that area roads have been slick enough lately to generate pileups, which sometimes precede next-day delay/closure decisions if conditions repeat.

With totalsnow_cm = 0 and only ~0.02 in liquid on the day, road clearing capacity isn’t the limiter. The operational risk is freezing fog (forecasted 5–9 AM around 30–31°F) causing sudden, patchy glaze/black-ice conditions—especially on bridge decks, ramps, and shaded rural connectors. Expect MDOT/KCRC to be in a normal winter posture: light overnight staffing, with salt/sand spot-treating if sensors/calls indicate slickness. Bus routes should be largely passable by 6:30 AM, but the ‘patchy and surprise’ nature of freezing fog keeps this from being a high-confidence all-clear.

webWeatherVerifier.verification_summary: For Rockford, MI (target school day Thu, Feb 19, 2026), the provided WeatherAPI forecast is relatively mild: temps around 30–31°F at 6–8 AM with feels-like about 24–25°F and light winds, plus freezing fog. Cross-checking web sources: Weather.com’s hourly page for Rockford shows Thu morning fog with ~35–36°F temps and “feels like” ~29–30°F (warmer than the API by ~4–6°F in the morning window). weatherUSA shows current conditions around low-40s with matching feels-like (useful for ‘now’ but not a detailed Thu-AM wind chill). No credible source located in this sweep shows any wind chill near -20°F for Thu morning; therefore, the automatic extreme-cold closure trigger is NOT supported. The more relevant operational risk from the API is freezing fog/low visibility and potential patchy slickness, not extreme cold or snow accumulation.

primary_factors: No accumulating snow expected; this is not a plowable event (0" forecast)
Freezing fog around the 6–8 AM bus window with temps near 30–31°F creates patchy black-ice risk (bridges/overpasses/shaded rural roads) and reduced visibility
Warming trend after mid-morning should improve conditions; afternoon impacts minimal
No confirmed neighboring-district closure domino signals and no Rockford weather announcement as of Wed evening
No widespread power-outage signal; grid risk appears low (but outage reporting has data gaps)
final.decision_rationale: All experts converge on a low closure probability (debate consensus ~15%) because there is no forecast snowfall/ice storm and winds/cold are not near Michigan extreme-cold closure thresholds. The single meaningful school-impact hazard is freezing fog during the morning bus window: it can abruptly lower visibility and create thin, patchy glaze/black ice on untreated surfaces (especially bridges and rural connectors) despite minimal measurable precipitation. In Michigan—and specifically mid/late February in West Michigan—this pattern historically results in schools staying open most of the time, with delays occurring more often than full closures when fog becomes dense/widespread. News/community intelligence shows no closure domino effect and no active district messaging; infrastructure and power-grid inputs do not show system-wide failures, though live road-condition and outage detail is limited. Net: recommend OPEN with monitoring, with a realistic but modest tail risk that decision-makers opt for a short delay if dense freezing fog/black ice is observed on early route checks.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Most likely: Open (possibly with extra caution messaging); only isolated slick spots and variable fog
alternative_scenarios.impact: Normal operations with slower travel on some secondary roads; emphasize lights/spacing and slick-spot awareness.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Borderline: 1–2 hour delay due to dense freezing fog and widespread slick spot reports at 5:30–6:30 AM
alternative_scenarios.impact: Allows daylight/temps to rise and crews to spot-treat; reduces bus-stop and low-visibility risk.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Low-probability: Full closure driven by unexpectedly widespread glaze/black ice or a localized power outage at key facilities
alternative_scenarios.impact: District-wide shutdown despite minimal precip; would require confirmation of systemic travel safety issues or facility outages.

for_schools: Recommendation: OPEN with monitoring (plan for a possible 1–2 hour delay only if early AM conditions verify worse than expected).

Run an early route check/driver spot reports between ~5:30–6:15 AM focused on bridges, hills, and rural fringe roads; if multiple routes report consistent sliding/low visibility (<1/4 mile), favor a DELAY over closure.
Pre-treat/salt building entrances, sidewalks, bus loops, and drop-off lanes before 6:30 AM; freezing fog can glaze these quickly.
Send a parent/staff message by ~6:00 AM emphasizing fog, headlights, slower speeds, and the ‘wet-looking pavement can be ice’ risk.
for_residents: Assume patchy black ice on bridges/overpasses and shaded roads around sunrise; increase following distance and avoid sudden braking.
Use low beams in fog; expect reduced visibility near rivers/low-lying areas.
If walking to bus stops, wear traction-capable footwear and allow extra time due to slick sidewalks/driveways.
for_authorities: Prioritize spot-treating bridges/ramps and known slick corridors 4:30–7:30 AM; fog-related glaze can be highly localized.
If available, push any RWIS/pavement-temp observations to public channels early AM (even brief notes help schools decide).
Monitor crash hotspots (US-131 ramps, M-44 connectors) for early incident spikes that could justify a delay advisory.

positions.rationale: For Rockford, MI on Thu 2026-02-19, the forecast does not resemble a classic snow-day setup: there’s no measurable snowfall, very little liquid precipitation during school hours, and winds are modest. The only credible closure driver is freezing fog during the pre-dawn through mid-morning period (especially ~6–8 AM), which can create patchy black ice on bridge decks, shaded/low-traffic roads, and rural connectors while also reducing visibility. In a West Michigan district accustomed to winter operations, that combination most often produces a cautionary commute (and sometimes a 1–2 hour delay) rather than a full closure. I therefore put full snow-day/closure odds in the low teens, with a meaningfully higher delay probability than closure.
keyFactors: No accumulating snow signal: totalsnow_cm = 0 and no snow hours; precip is minimal (~0.02" liquid) and mainly late night drizzle, so there’s no plowable event to justify closure.

Temperatures are marginal around the morning bus window (roughly 5–9 AM): forecast temp ~30–31°F with freezing fog noted for multiple hours. That supports patchy glaze/black ice risk despite near-zero QPF.
Primary impact is visibility/ice, not wind/cold: light winds (generally 4–8 mph in the morning, max wind ~13 mph) and wind chills ~24–25°F are uncomfortable but far from cold-closure thresholds.
Short-lived hazard window: temps rise above freezing by mid/late morning, so widespread all-day impacts are unlikely; this pattern typically favors “open” or at most a delay.
Antecedent wetness: heavy rain on Wed 2026-02-18 + overnight cooling increases refreeze potential on bridges/untreated rural roads, raising risk of localized slick spots at commute time.

positions.rationale: Net historical read: this is a classic “marginal ice/visibility morning” rather than a snow-day event. With totalsnow = 0 and warming to ~41°F (Thu 2026-02-19), full-day closures are uncommon; the tail risk comes from freezing fog/patchy glaze right at 6–8 AM plus localized microclimates (river lowlands, bridge decks, rural fringes). I land near the low end of my earlier 10–20% closure band because the hazards look transient and not paired with heavy precip or high winds—more consistent with a delay than a cancellation.
keyFactors: Historical closure patterns in West Michigan strongly favor “open” on thaw/transition days with **no accumulating snow** and highs in the low 40s; districts are fully winter-operational in mid/late February.

The *only* historically meaningful closure trigger in this setup is **patchy flash-freeze/black ice** tied to **freezing fog** during the bus window (roughly 5–9 AM) after a wet/mild prior day—this more often produces **delays** than full cancellations.

Fog/freezing fog can reduce visibility at bus stops and on rural connectors; historically, that increases the chance of a **late call delay** if route-checks find widespread slick spots, but rarely sustains an all-day closure when temps rise above freezing mid-morning.

Antecedent heavy rain/melt on Wed 2026-02-18 raises the ‘refreeze on bridges/untreated surfaces’ risk, but the forecast QPF on Thu is tiny and winds are modest—limiting broad, long-duration hazardous conditions.

positions.rationale: From a news-and-signals perspective, this looks like a ‘headline-light’ morning for Rockford on Thursday, February 19, 2026: no official closure messaging found, no neighboring-district domino effect, and no strong media framing of a Kent County ice storm. The credible operational risk is localized/patchy: freezing fog at or just below freezing near commute time could create surprise slick spots and reduced visibility. That pattern usually produces *delays* and cautionary driving advisories rather than full district-wide closures in West Michigan, especially with temperatures rising above freezing later in the morning and minimal precipitation totals. Net: low but non-trivial chance of a closure—driven almost entirely by how dense/widespread the freezing fog/black ice becomes pre-dawn.

Recent weather-related multi-vehicle crash on US-131 is a contextual warning that roads have been slick lately; if freezing fog produces a repeat of widespread slickness at 6–8 AM, decision-makers may lean toward a delay out of caution.

Power-grid disruption signals are not strong (no wind/ice accretion setup); outage data is also low-confidence due to Consumers’ reporting limitations, but nothing points to widespread outages forcing closure.

debates.topic: Your scoring implies fairly broad ‘significant’ commute impacts. From a meteorology standpoint, the main uncertainty is *how dense/widespread* the freezing fog becomes and whether pavement temps (not just air temps) fall below 32°F on enough of the network. If fog is shallow/patchy or pavement stays just above freezing on treated primaries, impacts could be much more localized than the score suggests.

positions.rationale: I’m keeping the closure (“snow day”) probability low but not zero because the meteorological hazards are *marginal-temperature icing* and *visibility*, not snowfall. The forecast places several consecutive hours of freezing fog right in the 6–9 AM commute, with temperatures just below freezing and extremely high humidity—classic conditions for patchy black ice on bridges/overpasses and shaded rural segments even with near-zero measured precip. However, the lack of accumulating snow, modest winds, and a clear warming trend toward/above freezing by late morning strongly favor schools remaining open (at most, a short delay if fog is dense/widespread at 6–8 AM). Compared with Round 1 (12%), I’m nudging to 14% to reflect the Safety agent’s emphasis on secondary-road/parking-lot icing and the ‘surprise’ nature of freezing-fog glaze, but I do not see enough meteorological forcing for a district-wide closure scenario.
keyFactors: No plowable snow signal: totalsnow_cm = 0, daily snow chance 0%; precip is minimal during the school-impacted window (most QPF shows up as a tiny late-evening drizzle).
Primary risk is *freezing fog* (forecast ~05:00–09:00) with temps hovering ~30–31°F: can deposit rime and create patchy glaze/black ice on untreated bridges, ramps, and low-traffic rural roads.
Visibility risk overlaps the bus window: freezing fog/mist could reduce sight distance near sunrise, which sometimes drives a *delay* decision even when roads are mostly OK.
Warming trend after mid-morning (above freezing by ~10–11 AM and low 40s later) limits duration/severity—argues against a full closure.
Winds are modest (max ~13 mph): no blowing snow/drifting, no wind-driven outage risk.

positions.rationale: As the HISTORY specialist, I weight how often this *type* of day becomes a closure in mid/late February in West Michigan. With no snowfall and improving temperatures, the base rate for a full closure is low. I do, however, adjust upward from a “near-zero” baseline because freezing fog at or below 32°F during the bus window—especially following a very wet prior day—has a documented tendency to create patchy black ice that can be worse than the QPF suggests. Net: a closure is possible but still more likely to be handled via targeted pre-treatment + caution messaging or a 1–2 hour delay rather than a full snow day.
keyFactors: No plowable snow signal at all (totalsnow_cm = 0; only ~0.02" liquid equivalent on Thu 2026-02-19). Historically, Rockford/Kent County districts rarely *close* for rain/fog alone in late February when winter ops are fully active.

The only historically meaningful closure trigger here is the narrow early-morning hazard window: freezing fog explicitly forecast roughly 5–9 AM with temps ~30–31°F during the bus window (6–8 AM). That pattern more often produces *delays* than full cancellations, but it can spike closures if it lays a thin glaze on untreated roads/bridge decks.

Strong antecedent setup for patchy refreeze: Wed 2026-02-18 shows heavy rain in the dataset followed by a drop toward/under freezing overnight. That is a classic West Michigan ‘looks wet = is ice’ morning risk on bridges, rural fringes, and low-lying corridors.
Warming trend after mid-morning (high ~41–42°F) historically suppresses full-day closures; decision-makers tend to prefer a delay when conditions are expected to improve quickly.
NWS Hydrologic Outlook supports a broader thaw/transition regime (melt + rain + high humidity). Historically this increases nuisance issues (ponding, visibility) more than district-wide shutdowns.

positions.rationale: I’m moving **down from the prior Safety 40%** because the broader panel (meteorology/history/news) is aligned that this is not a plowable event and that impacts are likely *transient and patchy* rather than widespread. From a safety lens, freezing fog at ~30°F is a real bus-risk (surprise ice + reduced visibility), but in a winter-capable West Michigan district it more commonly triggers (a) aggressive pretreatment + (b) a **1–2 hour delay** if needed, not a full closure. I still hold the closure probability above the ~12% cluster because freezing fog can produce disproportionate crash/slide-off risk on untreated secondary roads and bridge decks right at decision time, and the forecast explicitly flags freezing fog for multiple consecutive hours. Net: **18% chance of a full snow day/closure** for Thu 2026-02-19; I would put the *delay* probability meaningfully higher than that if we were tracking it separately.
keyFactors: Primary hazard is *freezing fog* during the bus/parent-commute window (roughly 5–9 AM) with air temps ~30–31°F: high potential for patchy glaze/black ice on bridges, ramps, shaded stretches, and low-traffic rural roads even with near-zero QPF.

Visibility risk: fog/freezing fog around sunrise can reduce sight distance at crossings and bus stops; this can drive operational decisions (esp. for elementary routes) even when pavement impacts are localized.
Warming profile limits duration: temps rise above freezing late morning and peak near ~41°F, so conditions should improve rather than deteriorate—this favors **delay > closure**.
No accumulating snow and light winds (max ~13 mph) reduce the odds of widespread, district-wide impassability or bus-safety shutdown.
Antecedent wetness (heavy rain/melt on Wed 2/18) increases the chance that ‘looks wet’ surfaces refreeze in pockets before treatment fully takes effect.

positions.rationale: From a news-and-operational-signals perspective for Thu, Feb 19, 2026, Rockford looks more like a ‘marginal, patchy hazard’ morning than a classic cancel-the-day event. The absence of (a) explicit district messaging, (b) widespread neighboring closures, and (c) a strong local-media/NWS narrative targeting Kent County for significant icing keeps the closure probability low. However, freezing fog at/below freezing during the bus window plus recent slick-road incidents supports keeping a non-trivial tail risk for a cautious call—most likely a delay rather than a full closure. Net: slightly above the 12% consensus from meteorology/history/news due to the real-world road-incident context and the “surprise black ice” nature of freezing fog.
keyFactors: Signal check: As of Wed, Feb 18, 2026, no Rockford Public Schools closure/delay post found and no clear neighboring-district domino effect surfaced in the quick scan (Forest Hills, etc.).

Forecast framing is ‘headline-light’ for Kent County: no obvious media narrative of a major ice storm centered on Rockford/Kent; the more prominent regional item is an NWS Hydrologic Outlook (river rise/ice-jam awareness), which rarely drives school closures by itself.

Weather-impact risk is real but localized: freezing fog around the morning bus window (roughly 5–9 AM) with temps near/just below 32°F can create patchy black ice and reduced visibility—this tends to produce delays more often than full closures in West Michigan, especially with warming above freezing later.

Recent context: a multi-vehicle crash on US-131 indicates roads have been slick enough recently that if freezing fog/black ice repeats in the same corridors, decision-makers may lean more cautious. Still, without an active advisory/warning aimed at Kent County, it’s a modest upward nudge, not a dominant driver.
No strong compounding factors detected: minimal precip during school hours, modest winds, and no clear power-outage spike signal in the captured snapshots.

debates.topic: The 40% closure probability feels too high given the meteorological ceiling: no snow accumulation, very light QPF during commute hours, and temps rising above freezing by mid-morning. I’d reframe most of that risk as *delay* probability rather than full closure unless you have evidence of widespread glazing/freezing rain (not just freezing fog).
debates.challenge: The 40% closure probability feels too high given the meteorological ceiling: no snow accumulation, very light QPF during commute hours, and temps rising above freezing by mid-morning. I’d reframe most of that risk as *delay* probability rather than full closure unless you have evidence of widespread glazing/freezing rain (not just freezing fog).

debates.topic: Your historical bands are reasonable, but I’d weight the ‘freeze–thaw + fog’ analogs slightly more heavily *if* antecedent wet pavement is widespread from Wed’s rain. The forecast’s near-32°F plateau for several hours is supportive of patchy refreeze; not a big change, but enough to keep closure odds out of the single digits.

debates.topic: Lack of public-facing headlines/alerts is informative, but freezing fog/black-ice mornings often don’t get prominent headlines. Decision-making can still swing on early bus-route checks; absence of buzz shouldn’t push probabilities too close to zero.
debates.challenge: Lack of public-facing headlines/alerts is informative, but freezing fog/black-ice mornings often don’t get prominent headlines. Decision-making can still swing on early bus-route checks; absence of buzz shouldn’t push probabilities too close to zero.

debates.topic: The 40% closure estimate feels high relative to historical district behavior for ‘patchy black ice + fog’ mornings with rapid improvement by late morning. Unless you’re implicitly assuming *widespread* glaze/treated-road failure (or visibility well below what’s shown), the more common operational outcome is delay/slow routes, not full closure. What specific threshold (e.g., expected areawide crashes, sustained sub-1/4 mile vis, confirmed widespread untreated icing) justifies jumping to 40%?

If you’re not already, consider slightly higher tail-risk for closure when freezing fog is *explicitly* forecast for multiple hours at bus time.

debates.topic: Lack of closure announcements on Feb 18 is weakly informative historically—many districts decide very late for marginal ice/fog mornings. I’d caution against overweighting “no buzz” as evidence conditions will be fine.

Patchy freezing fog typically drives delays and targeted spot-treating rather than full-district closures in this region—so 40% seems high unless you have evidence of expected dense fog + widespread glaze on secondary roads.

confidenceJourney.shiftReason: I’m keeping the closure (“snow day”) probability low but not zero because the meteorological hazards are *marginal-temperature icing* and *visibility*, not snowfall. The forecast places several consecutive hours of freezing fog right in the 6–9 AM commute, with temperatures just below freezing and extremely high humidity—classic conditions for patchy black ice on bridges/overpasses and shaded rural segments even with near-zero measured precip. However, the lack of accumulating snow, modest winds, and a clear warming trend toward/above freezing by late morning strongly favor schools remaining open (at most, a short delay if fog is dense/widespread at 6–8 AM). Compared with Round 1 (12%), I’m nudging to 14% to reflect the Safety agent’s emphasis on secondary-road/parking-lot icing and the ‘surprise’ nature of freezing-fog glaze, but I do not see enough meteorological forcing for a district-wide closure scenario.

As the HISTORY specialist, I weight how often this *type* of day becomes a closure in mid/late February in West Michigan. With no snowfall and improving temperatures, the base rate for a full closure is low. I do, however, adjust upward from a “near-zero” baseline because freezing fog at or below 32°F during the bus window—especially following a very wet prior day—has a documented tendency to create patchy black ice that can be worse than the QPF suggests. Net: a closure is possible but still more likely to be handled via targeted pre-treatment + caution messaging or a 1–2 hour delay rather than a full snow day.

I’m moving **down from the prior Safety 40%** because the broader panel (meteorology/history/news) is aligned that this is not a plowable event and that impacts are likely *transient and patchy* rather than widespread. From a safety lens, freezing fog at ~30°F is a real bus-risk (surprise ice + reduced visibility), but in a winter-capable West Michigan district it more commonly triggers (a) aggressive pretreatment + (b) a **1–2 hour delay** if needed, not a full closure. I still hold the closure probability above the ~12% cluster because freezing fog can produce disproportionate crash/slide-off risk on untreated secondary roads and bridge decks right at decision time, and the forecast explicitly flags freezing fog for multiple consecutive hours. Net: **18% chance of a full snow day/closure** for Thu 2026-02-19; I would put the *delay* probability meaningfully higher than that if we were tracking it separately.

From a news-and-operational-signals perspective for Thu, Feb 19, 2026, Rockford looks more like a ‘marginal, patchy hazard’ morning than a classic cancel-the-day event. The absence of (a) explicit district messaging, (b) widespread neighboring closures, and (c) a strong local-media/NWS narrative targeting Kent County for significant icing keeps the closure probability low. However, freezing fog at/below freezing during the bus window plus recent slick-road incidents supports keeping a non-trivial tail risk for a cautious call—most likely a delay rather than a full closure. Net: slightly above the 12% consensus from meteorology/history/news due to the real-world road-incident context and the “surprise black ice” nature of freezing fog.

keyDisagreements.topic: Your scoring implies fairly broad ‘significant’ commute impacts. From a meteorology standpoint, the main uncertainty is *how dense/widespread* the freezing fog becomes and whether pavement temps (not just air temps) fall below 32°F on enough of the network. If fog is shallow/patchy or pavement stays just above freezing on treated primaries, impacts could be much more localized than the score suggests.
positions: Your scoring implies fairly broad ‘significant’ commute impacts. From a meteorology standpoint, the main uncertainty is *how dense/widespread* the freezing fog becomes and whether pavement temps (not just air temps) fall below 32°F on enough of the network. If fog is shallow/patchy or pavement stays just above freezing on treated primaries, impacts could be much more localized than the score suggests.

keyDisagreements.topic: The 10–20% closure range seems plausible, but I’d weight the lower end unless we have evidence of widespread dense fog/very low vis (e.g., <1/4 mile) and confirmed early-morning pavement temps below freezing. With only trace QPF and quick warmup, ‘delay’ is the more climatologically consistent outcome than ‘closure.’
positions: The 10–20% closure range seems plausible, but I’d weight the lower end unless we have evidence of widespread dense fog/very low vis (e.g., <1/4 mile) and confirmed early-morning pavement temps below freezing. With only trace QPF and quick warmup, ‘delay’ is the more climatologically consistent outcome than ‘closure.’

keyDisagreements.topic: Recent crash context is useful, but it can overweight today’s risk if tomorrow’s fog/icing is not as widespread as the crash-night conditions. I’d avoid anchoring on incidents without confirming similar meteorological drivers (glaze/freezing rain vs. freezing fog).
positions: Recent crash context is useful, but it can overweight today’s risk if tomorrow’s fog/icing is not as widespread as the crash-night conditions. I’d avoid anchoring on incidents without confirming similar meteorological drivers (glaze/freezing rain vs. freezing fog).

keyDisagreements.topic: You frame precip type as “mixed,” but the hourly forecast shows **freezing fog** (deposition) as the key ice mechanism rather than measurable freezing rain. If we over-weight ‘mixed precip,’ we may overestimate widespread icing versus patchy glaze.
positions: You frame precip type as “mixed,” but the hourly forecast shows **freezing fog** (deposition) as the key ice mechanism rather than measurable freezing rain. If we over-weight ‘mixed precip,’ we may overestimate widespread icing versus patchy glaze.

keyDisagreements.topic: Road/ice risk is rated “high,” but historically **high patchy-ice risk** in a well-treated Michigan district tends to translate to *delay/route adjustments* unless there’s strong evidence of widespread untreated slickness. I’d like to see a clearer distinction between ‘patchy high-risk spots’ and ‘systemic network failure.’

collaboration.collaborationSummary: Agents reached consensus after 2 round(s) with 4.0% spread. Average probability: 15%.

alert.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued February 17 at 9:43AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Allegan, MI; Barry, MI; Calhoun, MI; Clinton, MI; Eaton, MI; Ingham, MI; Ionia, MI; Jackson, MI; Kalamazoo, MI; Kent, MI; Muskegon, MI; Ottawa, MI; Van Buren, MI
alert.desc:
ESFGRR

Steady melting of snow and ice over the last week has begun to cause
rivers to rise across the area. Several chances for rain this week
will add to these rises. Based on current expected rainfall, no
significant flooding is expected on West Michigan rivers, though
typical spring water level rises within the river channels will
happen.

Meanwhile, river ice has weakened significantly over the last week,
and as water levels rise any remaining ice will likely be broken and
start to move downstream. This creates the possibility for formation
of a few ice jams. Ice jams tend to form in the same places
repeatedly, so special attention should be paid in the Comstock Park
(Kent County) area as well as the Robinson Township (Ottawa County)
area along the Grand River.

Anyone living or working near West Michigan rivers should pay extra
attention this week as water levels rise. Have a plan to monitor and
respond if flooding develops unexpectedly.

Monitor the latest conditions at https://water.noaa.gov
